t: Proverbs 13
Contrast the Upright and the Wicked
A*pn wise son accepts*i his*i father’s discipline, But*ln a scoffer does not listen to rebuke.
From*ln the fruit of a man’s mouth he enjoys good, But*ln the desire of the treacherous is violence.
The*ln one who guards his mouth preserves his life; The*ln one who opens wide his lips comes to ruin.
The*ln soul of the sluggard craves and gets*i nothing, But*ln the soul of the diligent is made fat.
A*ln righteous man hates falsehood, But*ln a wicked man acts disgustingly and shamefully.
Righteousness*ln guards the one whose way is blameless, But*ln wickedness subverts the sinner.
There*ln is one who pretends to be rich, but has nothing; Another*iln pretends to be poor, but has great wealth.
The*ln ransom of a man’s life is his wealth, But*ln the poor hears no rebuke.
The*ln light of the righteous rejoices, But*ln the lamp of the wicked goes out.
Through*ln insolence comes nothing but strife, But*ln wisdom is with those who receive counsel.
Wealth*ln obtained*i by fraud dwindles, But*ln the one who gathers by labor increases it.*i
Hope*ln deferred makes the heart sick, But*ln desire fulfilled is a tree of life.
The*ln one who despises the word will be in debt to it, But*ln the one who fears the commandment will be rewarded.
The*ln teaching of the wise is a fountain of life, To*ln turn aside from the snares of death.
Good*ln understanding produces favor, But*ln the way of the treacherous is hard.
Every*ln prudent man acts with knowledge, But*ln a fool displays folly.
A*ln wicked messenger falls into adversity, But*ln a faithful envoy brings*i healing.
Poverty*ln and shame will*i come*i to him who neglects discipline, But*ln he who regards reproof will be honored.
Desire*ln realized is sweet to the soul, But*ln it is an abomination to fools to turn away from evil.
He*ln who walks with wise men will be wise, But*ln the companion of fools will suffer harm.
Adversity*ln pursues sinners, But*ln the righteous will be rewarded with prosperity.
A*ln good man leaves an inheritance to his children’s children, And*ln the wealth of the sinner is stored up for the righteous.
Abundant*ln food is*i in*i the fallow ground of the poor, But*ln it is swept away by injustice.
He*ln who withholds his rod hates his son, But*ln he who loves him disciplines him diligently.
The*ln righteous has enough to satisfy his appetite, But*ln the stomach of the wicked is in need.
